I’m not talking, I’m thinking. but how did I get here? what is this place? The test! yeah, that’s it! I was in a room taking part to a ...Rorschach test... what was the reason? Am I crazy? Was I performing the test or... taking it? And what are those people doing here? Maybe... the place looks like a hospital. Maybe I was injured. There is no pain though, no bruises maybe. either way, I am not taking my clothes off in front of these strangers to check on my body. Maybe I have a relation with them. Supposedly I have something to do to them... or they to me... I wonder what it is..."

Inside a mental institution, a group of people wakes up in the commons, the dining place of this sanitarium. nobody remembers how they got there. Amnesia. The only thing they remember is their names and an obscure scene of a Rorschach test. after searching the facility each one slowly begins to remember their role in this place... but that’s the easy part.

Sanitarium is a game in which, what you try to discover, is yourself! You try to remember, by gathering pieces of information and items in the facility, who you truly are and what's your purpose in the sanitarium. If you know who you are, then you have a purpose. If you fulfill your purpose, then you are the winner! This game is a tribute to all the b-movies that feature a main plot inside an abandoned hospital, asylum, sanitarium, medical building wing, or haunted medical lab.

The deduction mechanism of the game is very simple. It's allows you to bluff, in being one of the roles that exist in the game, until another player proves you wrong. If no one can prove you wrong then you fulfill your role's objective. There are six different objectives in the game that depend on the player's adopted role.

Sanitarium is best played with 3 to 6 players, but if you have a big group of friends it may be played with a maximum of 9 (if you don't bother with a little downtime, it repays in interactivity!).

Name: Spelet om Europa
Description: A roll and move trivia game of arbitrary length where players move across a map of Europe, answering historical, cultural and political questions about the continent. Published before the Swedish referendum on joining the European Union in 1994. There is no year of publication, but the extensive bibliography of recommended reading lists titles from the years 1991-2.

Name: AirWar: C21
Description:
Contemporary air combat miniature rules that strives to achieve the fine balance between playability and detail.  Suitable for 2 or more air gamers to reenact historical or hypothetical air war scenarios.  The rulebook includes "Strange Stuff" notes on equipment from Science Fiction for encounters with UFO's or 'special project' aircraft.  Any scale miniatures or aircraft counters will suffice.  A hex map or hex grid mat will be required.

From the back cover of the book:

"Airwar: C21 is a set of introductory modern air combat rules which combine playability and realism in an attempt to provide gamers with a simple yet challenging game of modern air warfare - retaining the spirit of the genre, without sacrificing the speed and excitement.

Utilising a unique 2D system to recreate the 3D maneuvers of dogfighting, AirWar: C21 is a perfect introduction for the newcomer to the fun of air wargaming as well as great for the more experienced 'old hand' looking for a simple yet enjoyable set of rules to introduce his 'groundpounder' friends to war in the skies."

Name: Super Route Le Mans travel game
Description: Racing game for on the road, comes in the form of an racing car that can be opened.  Inside you will find a circuit, some cars and the rules.  There are no dices.. You can spin the wheel instead. Two ways of playing the game : Spin the wheel and place your car forwards according to what you've spun or a car game like, first one to see a tree may spin the wheel..

Name: WW2
Description:
This game is Strategy WW2 Game.This game is a multiple player game. Each player becomes a leader in Japan, the United States, the German Soviet Union, and Britain, and makes good use of the combat and diplomacy.

Because the unit has the air force, the army, and naval forces, efficient operation is demanded.

It is not possible to win if the alliance is still important, and there is no strategy that conspires with allied forces to obtain the good chance to win in this game.

Name: Evil Lord
Description:
You are an Evil Lord in his Dark Throne in the Tower of Fear of his Castle of Skulls. Isn’t it obvious what your aim is? You want to conquer the world by building some kind of Doomsday Device! In order to do so, you will have to give orders to your lowly Minions which will try to perform evil deeds, collect valuable resources, spread terror, fight heroes and cause general mayhem. Oh, another thing: there seem to be a few other Evil Lords around who are trying to conquer the world themselves: you will have to do it before them.

Apart from your Dark Tower, there are 6 places in the Realm: the Countryside, the Wood, the Sanctuary, the City, the Castle and the Dungeon. There are 6 basic orders you could give to a Minion: Bring me some Gold, Bring me some Food, Bring me some Mana, attempt a Diplomacy Mission, attempt a War Mission, and Have some Fun. (Note that the Minion’s concept of "Diplomacy" includes poisoning, forging, stealing and so on). 
Each turn you could give to a Minion just 1 of these 12 orders, thus selecting either what must he door where should him go, by means of placement on an apposite  board. 
For example, if you assign him the task of recovering some Gold, he will decide by himself if looking for it in the Dungeon or in the Sanctuary or elsewhere. 
On the other hand, if you order him to go to the Wood, it will be upon to him to decide either of having some Fun, or looking for Mana, or else.  
The Minion will decide it by drawing an Evil Deed Card.

There are all sort of Evil Deeds, ranging  from "Poison the Good King in the Castle" to "Beat the Monks for Fun in the Sanctuary", an each will identify univocally both where the Minion will go and what will he try to do. 
The chance of actually being able to perform the Evil Deed will depend on chance (die roll), special ability of the Minion (such as "Violence", "Stealth", "Persuasion" and so on; each kind on Minion has his own) and on the nature of the Evil Deed. 
It could be that after the Evil Deed determination there are Minions of different Dark Lord in the same Place: in that case they will not tolerate the presence of the other(s) and they will fight until the other(s) will die. Also some Evil Deed Missions will involve a fighting with a Hero (randomly drawn from the Hero Deck). 
By performing Evil Deeds successfully you will be able to  collect basic resources (Gold, Food and Mana), Special Items (to increase the capabilities of your Minions), and components for your Doomsday devices.

In addition, as you progress in your path of darkness, you will become both feared and hated by the Heroes of the Realm: while being feared is a good thing (Aid Minions in combat), since will aid your minions in combat situations, being hated too much could bring trouble, since will increase the probability of you being attacked by Heroes.

Name: Lauras Geheimnis
Description:
own description:
A memory variant based on the Laura books (Baumhaus Verlag).
The goal is to uncover the 12 tiles in the right chronological order, then the winning child may retell the story with the aid of the motives of the tiles.

Amigo press release:
Eine ganz besondere Memory-Variante ist das Geschichten Memo Lauras Geheimnis. Zwölf Karten mit den kindgerechten Illustrationen von Klaus Baumgart liegen verdeckt in der Tischmitte. Nur wer alle Karten in der richtigen Reihenfolge nacheinander aufdeckt, kann das Spiel gewinnen. So entwickelt sich aus der Bildersuche nach und nach eine richtige kleine Geschichte, die das siegreiche Kind schließlich anhand der Bilder erzählen darf.

Name: Conquistadores
Description:
Athens, Carthage, Egypt, Phoenicians, Persia, Rome ... great empires dominating at different times of the known World, the Mare Nostrum. so named by the Romans, but that would have happened if everyone had been powerful at the same time? The empire that dominates the most valuable territories will be the World Conqueror.
Conquerors is a card game for 3-6 players in which, players are faced with their armies to conquer major territories and get treasures. At the end of the game, the player who wins the most points wins.


Atenas, Cartago, Egipto, Fenicia, Persia, Roma...grandes imperios dominadores en distintas épocas del mundo conocido, el Mare Nostrum así denominado por los romanos, pero que hubiera pasado si hubieran coincidido todos en su máximo esplendor. El imperio  que domine  los más valiosos  territorios será el Conquistador del Mundo.
Conquistadores es un juego de cartas para 3 - 6  jugadores, en el cual los jugadores se enfrentan con sus ejércitos para conquistar los territorios más importantes y conseguir tesoros. Al final del juego, el jugador que gane el mayor número de puntos será el ganador.

Name: Blockadebrecher
Description:
An asymmetric game in which one player controls the ship Hammerhai while the other controls three pirate ships. The goal of the Hammerhai is to break the pirate blockade and escape from the board. The pirate player, on the other hand, is out to catch and board the Hammerhai.

The odds, according to the designer, slightly favor the pirates.

Originally included in the DSA role-playing adventure B13: Der Streuner soll sterben.

Name: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
Description:
Description from manual

the card game consists of 4 games:

Happy Families
the object of the game is to collect as many families (groups of 4 cards that belong together) as possible.

Donkey
this card game consists of 14 pairs and one donkey-card. when a player loses al of his cards he is saved and stops playing. at the end of the game the player who still hass the donkey-card has lost, all other players win.

Pairs
the object of the game is to win the most pairs (a pair = 2 cards of the same family)

Snap
snap is a 2 player game where the object is to win all cards. one by one, players turn over their top card and place it in the centre making one pile. when a turned card matches the card emediately beneath it on the pile 'SNAP' is called. the players who calls 'SNAP' first takes the centre pile of cards and places them face down under their pile.

Name: Wheel of Fortune: Simpsons Edition
Description:
What happens when you combine Springfield's favorite family, The Simpsons, with the top-rated game show' Find out in this fun-for-the-family game! To play, simply spin the wheel and call a letter. Little by little, the puzzle is revealed... and all 96 of them are based on people, places and things from the hit show. Game includes puzzle board with Simpsons frame, 96 puzzles, solutions and instructions booklet, spinner card and play money.

There's also a 'Deluxe Edition' which comes in a tin

Name: Step Chain
Description:
The simple, yet challenging, strategic card game where you match your cards to continue your chain. But beware, as your opponents may add to your chain, breaking your chain or you may be forced to loose your links and double points.
Source: [ The Game Crafter].

Step Chain is a card game where players compete to create the longest connecting chain of cards, while trying to keep their pile of broken links (cards that could not be played) from building up. Players take turns playing cards from their hands on to their chains or the chains of their opponents. The chains must match both the color and position on the card. The basic set includes three colors and three possible positions. Players can also stop an opponent's chain from extending by playing an End Chain card which forces the player to play a different End Chain card to start their chain again. At then end of a round, scores are added up 1 pt for each card in the chain while deducting points for cards in their broken links pile.

Name: Umbra
Description:
DESCRIPTION:
The goal of Umbra is to move all five of your pieces to your victory zone. There are two players, North and South. Each player has five pieces. North's pieces are concave, South's pieces are convex. There are two zones on the board. Each zone consists of five positions marked by a nearby colored circle. The zones serve two purposes. At the start of game, each player takes turns placing their pieces in their starting zone. North's starting zone is at the top of the board, South's starting zone is at the bottom. North's starting zone is South's victory zone, and similarly, South's starting zone is North's victory zone. Once the placement phase has completed, the player's take turns moving one of their stones. The first player to move all of their pieces to the victory zone such that all piece colors match the color markings of the victory zone, wins.

Umbra has a puzzle like quality to it.

PIECE MOVEMENT:
Once all pieces have been placed, a piece can move in one of the follwing ways:

STEP move - The piece can move to any adjacent position. 
JUMP move - The piece can perform a non-capturing jump over an enemy piece as long as the target position advances the piece towards the victory zone. 
SWAP move - If your piece is adjacent to an enemy piece and the enemy piece is in your victory zone, the positions of the two pieces are exchanged.
Note: To make the move, drag your piece and drop it over the enemy piece.

Name: Battlecards: World Conflict – North African Campaign: Expansion Pack 1
Description:
Contents of each Expansion Pack:

1 top card (identifies Expansion Packs 1-5)
1 bottom card (identifies each card in the pack)
20 expansion cards (Arsenal & Conflict cards balanced to enhance game play and add new capabilities)

Name: Age of Steam Expansion: Sharing
Description:
All you’ve ever wanted to do in life is to connect all the locations where there are parties so that everyone can deliver gifts to each other...how fun is that? You know, of course, that people who build railroad companies are the most generous people in the world. They love to help out their competitors, with a motto of “all for the greater good” while having boatloads of fun. In this expansion, you’ll share track with your opponents while they share track with you. And all it takes to share? A share!

Yes, you’re still competing with other players to move all the gifts everyone has gotten for each other to the correct party, but you’re doing it with a wink of your eye and a fun little skip to your step. Sure, there’s still only one winner, but it’s really about how many friends you make while playing...and doesn’t that make everyone a winner?

Sharing is for 3 to 6 players who really care about other people.

If you find the “regular” Sharing rules for Ted Alspach’s Sharing Steam/Age of Steam expansion too competitive for your tastes, try this softer, more pleasant expansion map (on the reverse side of “Sharing”). You’ll be guaranteed to make more friends in Steam/Age of Steam than ever before!

What if Steam/Age of Steam was a truly cooperative game, like Shadows over Camelot with out a traitor? Or if no one had to die in Clue, so you could just mosey around that neat mansion talking to your friends? Or if there were no diseases in Pandemic, or no ghosts in Ghost Story? Wouldn’t that be fun? Sure it would!
Ted Alspach’s *Really* Friendly Sharing is for 2 to 10 players who don’t have some horribly recessive competitive gene.

In Ted Alspach’s *Really* Friendly Sharing, you work as a team to build a railroad. Many of the aspects that cause unnecessary tension in Age of Steam have been removed, like money and the AoS auction, so you can focus on laying track, making deliveries, getting VPs and having fun!

The 2010 Essen Aos/Steam map pack from Bezier Games features 8 new maps, including 6 mounted ones on 3 double sided expansions. These maps can be preordered from www.beziergames.com and will ship in October 2010. The “bonus” Sharing map is only available through preorders. Expansion #1: California Gold Rush & Underground Railroad, Expansion #2: Amazon Rainforest and Sahara Desert and Expansion #3: Atlantis and Trisland have been previously announced.

Name: Of Monsters and Men
Description:
Publisher's description:

During the time of the Romans monsters and gods shared the world of men. As time went by men cleared the ancient forests and created great cities. Men continue to grow in numbers while the mythical creatures of the forest, meadow, mountain and stream slowly dwindle to extinction.

You are one of the mythical races of ancient Europe, and must somehow survive the uprising of mankind. If you can eke out an existence until the land is covered with men then you have succeeded in your task.

Players take a race from the following:

     Trolls
     Vampires
     Dwarves
     Goblins
     Werewolves
     Gnomes
     Pixies
     Elves
     Giants
     Fairies


This is a free Print-n-Play boardgame.

User summary:

The players each take a type of monster, and start in a favored terrain.  Each monster has a special ability, such as Hide, Kill, Teleport, Magic, Befriend, etc.

Each turn you must play at least one card.  Some are mandatory, such as the growth of human population, while others are optional, such as use your Special Ability or grow your own monster population.

The object of the game is to find some havens in Europe where you can dwell in peace without humans destroying you.  Sending the men against your opponents is a common tactic: the less of them, the better for you.  But if there are too many humans, your plan may backfire as they then may expand into your territories.

Name: Beehive
Description:
Beehive is a fun simple game where players take on the role of a swarm of bees making honey. A game usually take 6-8 rounds and lasts about 30-45 minutes.

Each player starts with a swarm of bees and each bee is carrying a different amount of nectar.  On a round different areas of the hive are made available to fly bees into.  Using a secret bidding mechanic players deploy their bees in the different locations.  The player who brings most nectar to an area claims ownership of that area of the hive.

Points are then scored each round for making honey. If a player can claim groups of areas they will score more points.

Players can also influence the hive by bidding on cards which give extra points, extra drone bees or more significantly the 'swarming' cards allow players to swap ownership of different areas of the hive.

However at the end of a round the player with least points can remove a honey marker from the board and keep things balanced.

Beehive was designed to be a quick fun game with a 'stop the leader' ethos in its design.

Not to be confused with Beehive

Name: QuUMP
Description:
Tag Line:  The exciting bump and jump game

From the instructions:
The first objective in a QuUMP game is to "QuUMP", which means moving your playing pieces all from start to home in the fewest turns.

My understanding of the game:
QuUMP is a Parcheesi-like game in which a player must get his pieces from his start position to the center home spot.  The game can be played by two to four players each using one of the colors: blue, green, red, or yellow.  What is unique about this game are the playing pieces.  Each piece is about 1/2 inch in height and pieces are of various shapes.  If you look straight down on the pieces from above, the shapes are: square, triangle, circle, diamond, and octagon.  Furthermore, the square pieces come in three sizes: small, medium, and large.  In the basic game, only three of the shapes are used.  Many advanced variations exist, including one in which all the shapes are used.

The game board has a series of tracks that lead from the start area to home.  Each piece must follow the track that matches its shape.  The square piece must follow the square track, the circular piece must follow the circular track and so on.  The tracks connect to each of the player's start areas to the central home area and hence intersect with each other.

Certain points on the tracks and intersections allow players to jump their piece over other pieces or to bump opponents pieces back along their respective tracks.

Finally, players can roll up to five dice (just once) to gain additional movement points.  Players must cover the numbers 1 to 6 with the five dice.  Two or more dice can be used to cover one number.  For example, on a roll of 1-2-2-3-6, the player could cover the numbers 1, 2, 5, and 6.  In this example, 3 and 4 would be left uncovered, allowing the player to move pieces an additional seven spaces.

The first player to move all of his pieces to home is the winner.
